meta.title: Polycystic kidney disease and other renal cysts

content:
Introduction

Polycystic kidney disease most often refers to autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), the primary focus of this article.  ADPKD is the most common inherited kidney disorder, affecting approximately 1 in 400 to 1,000 people worldwide.  It is a systemic disorder that primarily affects the kidneys causing fluid-filled cysts, but it can also involve other organs, particularly the liver, pancreas, and cerebral vasculature.  ADPKD typically manifests in adulthood, with symptoms often appearing between ages 30 and 50, and can lead to kidney dysfunction, hypertension, and eventually end-stage renal disease (ESRD).



Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is less common and primarily affects young children; ARPKD and other cystic kidney disease are briefly discussed in the differential diagnosis section of this article.

Pathophysiology



ADPKD results from mutations in genes that encode proteins involved in various cellular processes, including cell division, differentiation, and fluid secretion.  Two genes are primarily associated with ADPKD:



  • PKD1 gene (80% of cases):  Located on chromosome 16 and encodes the protein polycystin-1.
  • PKD2 gene (15% of cases):  Located on chromosome 4 and encodes the protein polycystin-2.


Polycystin-1 and polycystin-2 are thought to function together as a complex in primary cilia of kidney tubule cells (in addition to liver and pancreatic cells).  They play crucial roles in cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions, signal transduction, and regulation of cell proliferation and differentiation.  When these proteins are dysfunctional due to genetic mutations, it leads to:



  • Increased cell proliferation in kidney tubules
  • Increased fluid secretion into cyst cavities
  • Abnormal cell-matrix interactions
  • Alterations in tubular basement membrane


These changes result in the formation and progressive enlargement of cysts (

image 1
), which compress and damage surrounding healthy kidney tissue, leading to fibrosis and progressive kidney dysfunction (ESRD is common, ~50% of patients by age 60).  Antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, plays a significant role in promoting cyst growth by promoting fluid secretion into cysts.  Cyst expansion leads to localized renal ischemia and increases renin release; this activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), resulting in hypertension.  Polycystins are also found in endothelial and vascular smooth muscle cells, predisposing to extrarenal manifestations (eg, cerebral aneurysms).

Genetics and inheritance



ADPKD follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, meaning that an affected parent has a 50% chance of passing the disease to each child.  Notable genetic features of ADPKD include:



  • Variable expressivity:  The severity and progression of the disease can vary significantly, even within the same family.
  • Age-dependent penetrance:  Although the genetic mutation is present from birth, cysts typically develop and enlarge over time, with clinical manifestations usually appearing in adulthood.
  • Genotype-phenotype correlations:
    • PKD1 mutations generally lead to more severe disease with earlier onset of ESRD than PKD2 mutations (20 years earlier on average).
    • Truncating PKD1 mutations are typically associated with more severe disease.
  • Two-hit hypothesis:  While one mutated allele is inherited, a "second hit" or somatic mutation in the normal allele may be necessary for cyst formation, explaining the focal nature of cyst development.


The cystic degeneration of the renal parenchyma begins early in life, although most patients remain asymptomatic until age 30-40 when cysts have become large and numerous.

Clinical presentation



The clinical manifestations of ADPKD are diverse and can vary significantly among affected individuals.  Many patients may be asymptomatic for years, with the disease often discovered incidentally during imaging studies performed for unrelated reasons.  The most common early disease manifestations include:



  • Flank/abdominal pain:  Due to stretching of the renal capsule (chronic pain) or to cyst infection or hemorrhage (acute pain)
  • Hematuria:  Can be from cyst rupture into the renal collecting system or nephrolithiasis (uric acid stones can be seen due to acidic urine)
  • Hypertension:  Typically precedes any clinically detectable renal dysfunction and its progression correlates with the cystic structural derangement of the kidneys
  • Polyuria and polydipsia:  Due to an impaired urinary concentrating ability (from impaired sensitivity to ADH)


Major extrarenal complications of ADPKD are:



  • Intracranial aneurysms:  Nearly 5% of young adults and 20% of patients >age 60 develop intracranial aneurysms that can rupture causing intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage (eg, "thunderclap" headache).
  • Hepatic (up to 80% of patients) and pancreatic cysts
  • Cardiac valve disease and aortic root dilatation
  • Diverticulosis

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of ADPKD typically involves a combination of family history, imaging studies, and laboratory testing.  Ultrasonography is often the initial imaging modality (

image 2
), but it is not as sensitive as a CT scan (
image 3
); MRI is most sensitive for detecting small cysts.



Given that the incidence of benign kidney cysts increases with age, diagnostic criteria for ADPKD for patients with a positive family history include:



  • Age 15-39: â‰¥3 unilateral or bilateral kidney cysts
  • Age 40-59: â‰¥2 cysts in each kidney
  • Age â‰¥60: â‰¥4 cysts in each kidney


In patients without a family history, the diagnosis is made if there are â‰¥10 cysts per kidney.



Complete blood count may show an elevated hemoglobin in some patients (due to increased erythropoietin production, possibly from local ischemia around the renal cysts).  Genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis and identify the specific gene mutation, which is particularly useful in patients with no family history or for family planning.



Early recognition of ADPKD aids in family planning and the management of potential disease complications.  Screening should be performed via renal ultrasonography in individuals â‰¥18 years with a family history of ADPKD.  For patients diagnosed with ADPKD who have a family history of cerebral aneurysm or subarachnoid hemorrhage, or those in high-risk occupations (eg, airline pilots), screening for cerebral aneurysms should be performed (CT or MR angiography).

Management



Management of ADPKD focuses on slowing disease progression by limiting cyst growth and controlling blood pressure:



  • ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers:  Preferred due to their inhibitory effect on the RAAS and may also slow cyst growth (angiotensin II may be a growth factor) 
  • Low-salt diet (â‰¤2 g sodium/day):  Helps control intravascular volume and blood pressure, preserving renal function
  • Suppression of ADH (ADH stimulates cyst growth):  ADH levels are reduced with high fluid intake (>3 L/day) and inhibited using tolvaptan (a V2 receptor ADH antagonist requiring monitoring due to potential liver toxicity)


Pain management options include analgesics, cyst drainage, or, rarely, surgical decompression.  The disease progresses to ESRD in about 50% of patients by age 60, necessitating dialysis and consideration for kidney transplantation.  Nephrectomy is occasionally performed in select patients (eg, intractable pain or anorexia due to gastric compression).



Family planning and genetic counseling should be offered given the strong genetic basis of the disease.  Psychological counseling is beneficial because the diagnosis of ADPKD may result in psychological consequences, have an impact on career decisions, and potentially affect ability to obtain life insurance.

Differential diagnosis

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD)



Less commonly, polycystic kidney disease can be due to ARPKD, which typically affects children.  ARPKD is due to a deficiency in fibrocystin (protein found in epithelial cells of renal tubules), leading to diffuse microcysts and impaired kidney function.  This can cause anuria or oliguria in utero, resulting in severe oligohydramnios and risk of Potter sequence.  Potter sequence is a predictable series of anomalies caused by fetal compression from insufficient amniotic fluid (

figure 1
).  Findings include:



  • Flattened facies:  Extrinsic fetal compression leads to a flattened, depressed nasal bridge; prominent epicanthal folds; low-set ears; and a recessed chin.
  • Limb deformities:  Restricted fetal movement causes deformities such as contractures, hip dislocation, and clubfoot.
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia:  Restricted thoracic expansion limits fetal lung development, causing respiratory distress and decreased breath sounds after birth.  Amniotic fluid is thought to promote production of elastin, collagen, and vascular endothelial growth factor in fetal lungs, and oligohydramnios likely results in reduced alveolarization and angiogenesis.


Potter sequence is often fatal in infancy, and patients who survive typically develop chronic lung and kidney disease.



In rare cases, severe ADPKD can present similarly in the neonatal period similar to ARPKD, although some ultrasound features may be different (eg, liver abnormalities).  Most pediatric patients with ADPKD are diagnosed incidentally (eg, imaging done for another cause) or in the setting of a positive family history.

Other renal cysts and lesions



Renal cysts can also be found in patients without polycystic kidney disease.  Most of these simple renal cysts (benign), although they can sometimes be malignant (eg, renal cell carcinoma).  Radiographic features suggesting a simple renal cyst include (

image 4
):



  • Sharply demarcated cyst with a smooth, thin wall
  • Homogenous fluid within the cyst with a density similar to water
  • No enhancement with radiocontrast


Simple renal cysts can be solitary or multiple and bilateral.  Most require no treatment or further monitoring (

).  Types of renal lesions that can typically be identified on imaging include hemorrhagic or proteinaceous cysts, angiomyolipoma (benign smooth muscle neoplasms), and some vascular abnormalities (eg, arteriovenous malformations).

Summary



The most common type of polycystic kidney disease is autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), which is usually caused by mutations in the PKD1 (80% of cases) or PK2D2 (15% of cases) genes.  These mutations lead to dysfunction of polycystin proteins, resulting in the formation and growth of renal cysts.  ADPKD typically manifests between age 30 and 50, with hypertension often preceding detectable renal dysfunction.  Key extrarenal manifestations include hepatic cysts and cerebral aneurysms.



Blood pressure control is key, namely in the form of RAAS inhibition (eg, ACE inhibitors).  Given that antidiuretic hormone (ADH) promotes cyst formation and growth, reducing ADH secretion (>3 L/day fluid intake) and/or inhibiting ADH (eg, tolvaptan) are important.  For patients progressing to end-stage renal disease, dialysis and kidney transplantation are necessary.



Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is more commonly seen in children and, if severe, may be associated with Potter sequence.  Renal cysts do not always represent polycystic kidney disease; simple cysts can often be distinguished from complex cysts based on their radiographic features.
